image.altText: 'Walk together to a better future': Linda Burney responds to the Liberal Party's opposition to the Voice

items.synopsis: Indigenous Australians Minister Linda Burney names four priorities for the proposed Voice to Parliament in a speech to the National Press Club, after growing pressure to detail how it would benefit First Nations people.

title.children: Linda Burney says gaps in health and education are among key priorities for the Voice

image.altText: A sandstone building

title.children: Daughter of man shot dead by his wife says she sees his body every time she closes her eyes

image.altText: A woman in a denim jacket sits with her hands clasped.

items.synopsis: The ACT government has announced a new 14-bed Adolescent Unit as part of the Centenary Hospital expansion after years of young mental health patients calling for a dedicated facility.

title.children: After years of children being admitted to Canberra's Adult Mental Health Unit, a dedicated facility for teens has opened

image.altText: A smiling woman with white hair.

items.synopsis: NSW Police Senior Constable Kristian White appears in court via video link charged with tasering 95-year-old dementia patient Clare Nowland, who died days later.

title.children: Magistrate 'disgusted' with prosecutors as police officer charged with tasering 95yo faces court via video link

image.altText: A toddler strapped into a pram.

items.synopsis: A man has been charged with the murder of 17-month-old toddler Ronan Davies, who was rushed to Adelaide's Women's and Children's Hospital but died two days later.

title.children: Man charged with murder of 17-month-old toddler Ronan Davies

image.altText: Bright green artificial turf out the front of a house.

items.synopsis: Artificial turf is an increasingly popular choice for suburban backyards, offering an evergreen surface that requires little maintenance. But that convenience comes with a big environmental price tag.

title.children: Thinking about rolling out artificial turf? Experts are urging you to consider natural alternatives

image.altText: Jake sits in a chair while receiving treatment

items.synopsis: Jake Usher wants you to talk about poo, and not for frivolous reasons. Last year, at the age of 31, he was diagnosed with stage 4 bowel cancer. Look back on our expert Q and A.

title.children: Jake thought bowel cancer was an old person's disease — until he was diagnosed

image.altText: A serious-looking Chinese woman in a blue suit stands at a podium and gestures with her hand.

title.children: China accuses Australia of 'flagrant slandering' as Hong Kong doubles down on arrest warrants for Australian residents

image.altText: A woman wearing pink pulling gym equipment

items.synopsis: A world-first study from Australian researchers has found the likely reason why breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy commonly experience reduced cognitive function.

title.children: Deirdre's brain fog was so bad she forgot what day it was. Scientists now know why

image.altText: woman standing looking down barrel holding baby boy, she has brown hair and is wearing glasses, baby has big blue eyes

items.synopsis: Home owners are struggling with increasing repayments amid reports that regional house prices have stagnated, despite interest rates staying on hold on Tuesday.

image.altText: A man in a blue shirt stands in a builders workship

items.synopsis: The thunderous sound of distant missile strikes is a frequent reminder that Manfred Hin is a long way from his north Queensland home.

image.altText: An illustration of artists JK-47, Alex Lahey and Sarah Blasko

items.synopsis: More than 840 cover songs have been played in the triple j studios across 20 years. The data shows us how artists craft a cover song.

title.children: Some of the world's biggest songs are covers. What makes a good one?

image.altText: Francene Jacques, with shoulder-length brown hair and wearing glasses and and pink cardigan, smiles slightly.

items.synopsis: With reports of elder abuse on the rise in Australia, these women in their 80s are sharing their stories in the hope that others seek the help they need.

title.children: The small acts of violence that led 81-year-old Francene to understand she was experiencing elder abuse

image.altText: A close up of a smiling woman wearing a traditional dress on a Bhutanese square.

items.synopsis: After centuries of isolation, Bhutan opened its doors to tourism in the 1970s. But when the ABC was granted rare entry into the country, it found a nation losing a high proportion of people — mainly to Australia.

title.children: 'It feels so empty': The forbidden kingdom of Bhutan is turning into a ghost town

image.altText: Philip Lowe sitting at a desk behind a microphone mid-sentence, gesturing with his right hand and looking at the camera

items.synopsis: Australian home borrowers are experiencing much, much more interest rate pain than borrowers in New Zealand, Canada, the UK or US – for one simple reason, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: The simple reason why Australian mortgage borrowers are in more pain than those in other countries

image.altText: Jingai Zhang.

items.synopsis: Tobias Pick, who pleaded guilty to the 2020 strangulation manslaughter of Tasmanian sex worker Jingai Zhang is to be paroled after serving half of his five-year jail term and will be deported to Germany.

title.children: German backpacker who killed Tasmanian sex worker to be paroled and deported

image.altText: dog digging

items.synopsis: They're our furry, four-legged best friends, but dogs — like all pets — come with their challenges. We asked for your curly questions on canine ownership and you sent through hundreds. Here are some of the more common experiences, and our experts' advice.

title.children: You sent our experts hundreds of questions on dog behaviour. Here's what we learnt

image.altText: A composite of Ash Barty and her newborn baby.

items.synopsis: Former world number one tennis player Ash Barty announces the birth of her first child, Hayden.

title.children: 'Our beautiful boy': Australian tennis great Ash Barty gives birth to son

image.altText: a graphic of a middle aged man with a comissioner at lecturn behind him, and two women

title.children: Final Robodebt report to speak to 'the most terrifying power of all': expert

image.altText: A flat white drone with four rotors in flight with trees in the background.

items.synopsis: The Defence Department, police and border agents have grounded DJI drones over security concerns, but questioning from one senator has confirmed the devices are still used widely across government.

title.children: DJI drones in wide use across government departments despite defence, Border Force bans

image.altText: Rene Caris handballs for Geelong

items.synopsis: Rene Caris admitted to feeling a little gun-shy when she returned from a mandatory two-week lay-off with concussion. Now, Heather Anderson's CTE diagnosis has put those concerns into sharp focus.

title.children: Concussion concerns aired as professional footballers head into finals following landmark CTE ruling

image.altText: Nusantara presentation in Singapore

items.synopsis: Joko Widodo heads home from Sydney with a promise of more assistance from Australia towards his legacy plan of building a new capital city on the island of Borneo.

title.children: Indonesia's 'clean, green, high-tech' new capital city is proving hard to sell to private investors around the world

image.altText: A woman smiles as her two small children sit at the top of a slide.

items.synopsis: Numerous studies show universal early childhood education provides a huge boost to the economy. The federal government is currently determining whether it will be introduced in Australia.

title.children: Studies show universal child care would result in sizeable boost to Australia's economy. So why don't we have it?

image.altText: A yellow Ray White sign that says "lease" in front of a freestanding home.

items.synopsis: Australia's housing crisis continues as rents increase again over the June quarter. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Rents rise and there are fears of a recession if the RBA raises rates again, ASX loses ground

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Car park operator Secure Parking has been accused by the consumer regulator of misleading customers. The ACCC is taking Secure Parking to court for making misleading claims about its Secure a Spot service. It alleges that over a five year period from 2017 to 2022, the company told consumers that they could reserve a parking spot when they chose, but this was not the case. ACCC commissioner Liza Carvers says Secure Parking's car parks were sometimes full before people with a booking arrived, which meant they didn't get a spot. “Some of the consumers who were unable to access the parking space they’d booked complained that they were late to, or entirely missed, appointments, events, and work commitments,” Ms Carver said. “Anyone who has ever driven into a capital city CBD will know that pre-booking a parking space helps puts your mind at ease." “We have commenced these court proceedings because we allege Secure Parking was not providing the service it was representing to consumers, and did not reserve a parking space after consumers had pre-booked using the Secure-a-Spot service.” ACCC is seeking penalties, compliance orders and costs against the company. Secure Parking is majority owned by Japanese car park operator Park24, which has 881 car parks and 318,000 car spaces across five countries.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Secure Parking accused of breaking consumer law

children.content: Car park operator Secure Parking has been accused by the consumer regulator of misleading customers.
The ACCC is taking Secure Parking to court for making misleading claims about its Secure a Spot service.
It alleges that over a five year period from 2017 to 2022, the company told consumers that they could reserve a parking spot when they chose, but this was not the case.
ACCC commissioner Liza Carvers says Secure Parking's car parks were sometimes full before people with a booking arrived, which meant they didn't get a spot.
“Some of the consumers who were unable to access the parking space they’d booked complained that they were late to, or entirely missed, appointments, events, and work commitments,” Ms Carver said.
“Anyone who has ever driven into a capital city CBD will know that pre-booking a parking space helps puts your mind at ease."

“We have commenced these court proceedings because we allege Secure Parking was not providing the service it was representing to consumers, and did not reserve a parking space after consumers had pre-booked using the Secure-a-Spot service.”
ACCC is seeking penalties, compliance orders and costs against the company.
Secure Parking is majority owned by Japanese car park operator Park24, which has 881 car parks and 318,000 car spaces across five countries.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX 200 remains in the red with most sectors lower as investors worry about a recession. Banks and energy stocks are among the losers, while utilities and miners are slightly higher. Agribusiness Elders (+3.8 per cent) did the best, while AMP (-4.4 per cent) did the worst after losing a court case brought by financial advisers for compensation. An environmental court dismissed a legal case against the extension of Whitehaven Coal's Narrabri underground mine. Whitehaven (-0.9 per cent) won approval last year in New South Wales, but still faces Federal Government approval for the mine extension. Treasury Wines rose after announcing the closure of its Karadoc commercial winery in Victoria by mid next year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX 200 lower at lunchtime

children.content: The ASX 200 remains in the red with most sectors lower as investors worry about a recession.
Banks and energy stocks are among the losers, while utilities and miners are slightly higher.
Agribusiness Elders (+3.8 per cent) did the best, while AMP (-4.4 per cent) did the worst after losing a court case brought by financial advisers for compensation.
An environmental court dismissed a legal case against the extension of Whitehaven Coal's Narrabri underground mine.
Whitehaven (-0.9 per cent) won approval last year in New South Wales, but still faces Federal Government approval for the mine extension.
Treasury Wines rose after announcing the closure of its Karadoc commercial winery in Victoria by mid next year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: China's services industry expanded at the weakest pace in five months in June with worries of a double dip slowdown. The Caixin/S & P Global services purchasing managers' index eased to 53.9 in June from 57.1 in May. That is the lowest reading since January when COVID-19 cases surged after restrictions were lifted. Caixin's composite reading of both services and manufacturing fell to 52.5 from 55.6 in May. "Employment contracted, deflationary pressure mounted, and optimism waned in the manufacturing sector," said Wang Zhe, senior economist at Caixin Insight Group. "Meanwhile, the services sector continued a post COVID rebound, but the recovery was losing steam." Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: China facing double dip slowdown

children.content: China's services industry expanded at the weakest pace in five months in June with worries of a double dip slowdown.
The Caixin/S
P Global services purchasing managers' index eased to 53.9 in June from 57.1 in May.
That is the lowest reading since January when COVID-19 cases surged after restrictions were lifted.
Caixin's composite reading of both services and manufacturing fell to 52.5 from 55.6 in May.
"Employment contracted, deflationary pressure mounted, and optimism waned in the manufacturing sector," said Wang Zhe, senior economist at Caixin Insight Group.
"Meanwhile, the services sector continued a post COVID rebound, but the recovery was losing steam."
Reuters
